Performance Measure Name: Number of new City-owned affordable units  developed through leveraged federal or provincial  funding
Story behind the number: The City continues to leverage federal and provincial funding for new development and redevelopment. The data for this measure is counted when the units are opened for occupancy. City projects in development are progressing, but no new units will be opened in 2024. The Affordable Housing Program aims to deliver up to 400 new City-owned housing developments and/or regenerated homes by 2026.

Performance Measure Name: Number of new affordable units planned for development by non-market housing providers that are supported through City initiatives
Story behind the number: As of Q1, 29 new non-market housing units have been approved at the development permit stage. Thirteen of these units were supported through the City’s Housing Incentive Program. Considering the number of City-led initiatives and key programs, including the allocation of eight parcels of land to non-profit providers to create over 400 non-market units, the number of units in the development permit stage is expected to increase throughout the rest of 2024.

Performance Measure Name: Applicants' level of satisfaction with the  Home Program (per cent)
Number of affordable housing units built through the Non-Market Housing Land Sale
Applicants' level of satisfaction with the  Housing Incentive Program (per cent)
Decision Timeliness Rate (per cent of decisions rendered on-time)
Story behind the number: Work has been done by Assessment Review Board leadership to prioritize the issuance of decisions within the statutory timelines. It is still early in the Assessment Review Board hearing season, and it is expected that more complex cases will be heard later in the year.

Performance Measure Name: Hearing Participants' Rate of Satisfaction with process information (per cent)
Story behind the number: Participants who reported they were not satisfied with the customer service they received also included comments indicating dissatisfaction with the hearing process and outcomes.

Performance Measure Name: Assessment Review Board decision publication on-time rate (per cent)
Story behind the number: The City Clerk’s Office has seven days to publish decisions of the Assessment Review Board. Staff cross-training has been effective in allowing for the timely publishing of decisions.

Performance Measure Name: Cases filed with a tribunal on which a decision is issued (per cent cases filed)
Story behind the number: The Assessment Review Board has the largest number of files of all the City’s tribunals. Withdrawals and mutual agreements are continuing at a high volume, resulting in a low number of files being heard. It is anticipated that this number will increase as the hearing season progresses and more files will be heard in the third and fourth quarter of 2024.

Performance Measure Name: Tribunal decisions overturned by an appeal body in a calendar year (per cent)
Story behind the number: Most Tribunal decisions are not appealed to a higher court.

Performance Measure Name: Public Art projects delivered by Calgary  Arts Development (per cent)
Story behind the number:
Major projects working towards completion in Q3 include the installation of four artworks in northeast Calgary and the mural panel project in Chinatown, and the development of an exhibit of Indigenous artworks is scheduled for display in Q4.
 
The City will continue to steward the public art collection and deliver on Truth and Reconciliation through art, while Calgary Arts Development Authority (CADA) will commission new work. 

CADA public art has commissioned an artist to begin several projects approved by the Interdepartmental Public Art Team.

Performance Measure Name: Amount of City funding per festival and  event attendee (dollars)
Story behind the number:
The mid-year dollar amount is not representative of the year-end total because most events are delivered in the last half of the year.

Due to the timing of post-event reports, the mid-year amount is a predicted estimate as of June 12. This is based on expected event totals for the first half of the year.

Festival and Event Subsidy Program funding continued to build on our 2023 goal of increasing the number of low-cost or no-cost festivals and events. These events are more accessible and improve equitable access for Calgarians and visitors.

Performance Measure Name: Number of community organizations receiving Arts & Culture microgrants
Story behind the number:
Eighty-six organizations were approved so far in 2024 for Arts and Culture Microgrant funding, 50 of which are first-time recipients. $1.03 million in funding will be awarded in 2024, supporting over 94 local initiatives. 

As of May 31, eight initiatives approved in 2024 were delivered for $35,681, engaging 3,487 attendees and 345 volunteers. Recipients worked with 116 community organizations and 85 local businesses, with 259 local artists supported.

The program supports as many organizations as possible, increasing the diversity of opportunities offered to Calgarians.

Performance Measure Name: Calgarians' satisfaction with Arts & Culture (per cent)
Building permit applications where issuance timeline commitments were met (per cent)
Story behind the number: Performance in meeting timeline commitments is sensitive to service demand and was significantly impacted by a 23% year-over-year increase in permit applications (over 14,000) received during the first six months of the year.  In the time period, 20% more permits were successfully issued than in the same period last year. To address increasing permit volumes, several initiatives have been undertaken: 1) Additional staff have been added to key areas of the business. 2) The City has expanded the Codes Office to support officers with interpretations of building codes.  3) Two new "Guides to Complete Application" have been released for customers.

Performance Measure Name: Inspection booking dates with appointments available within the next two business days (per cent)
Story behind the number: The number of building inspections booked in the first half of the year increased by 9%, reaching over 34,000.  Despite the rise in demand, the average time to book an inspection remained consistent with last year at four business days.  However, the increased demand continues to put pressure on booking availability within two business days.  To improve inspection booking capacity, the City hired additional staff and rolled out a non-standard 40 hour workweek for safety codes officers.  The City has also introduced enhancements to the Inspections Booking System and opened a dedicated Inspections Call Centre.

Performance Measure Name: Issued permits for new buildings with 5 or more storeys with an approved Public Protection Site Safety Plan (per cent)
New low-density dwellings with energy labelling (per cent)
Average customer satisfaction survey result (per cent)
Business licence applications that have been submitted and completed online - Ease of Service (per cent)
Customer Satisfaction (per cent)
Story behind the number: Peaking at 92.5 per cent in May 2024, the average rate of satisfaction in 2024 Mid-Year was 91 per cent, based on responses from 491 completed surveys. Notably, we have seen a significant increase in both the number of customer surveys submitted and the positive survey results. Addressing areas of opportunities identified through survey feedback, such as intakes, and enhancing file management processes and accountability, will be the primary focus and motivation in pursuit of the determined 2026 target of 96 per cent satisfaction.

Performance Measure Name: Licence Issuance Timeline (per cent of business licence applications where issuance timeline commitments were met)
Story behind the number:
As the volume of licences has steadily increased, the percentage of business licenses meeting their timeline commitments has kept pace. This performance extends to commercial licensing as well, noting a 22 per cent increase in new applications.

The average performance rate for the first five months of 2024 of 76 per cent has shown a significant increase compared to the same period in the previous year of 69.9 per cent. This upward trend shows our efforts are effective, but there's still room for improvement, highlighting the need for ongoing refinement of processes based on customer feedback.

Performance Measure Name: Business Opening Timeline (per cent of business licence applications for commercial-based businesses with licence issued on or before the intended open date)
Business Safety (per cent of business licensing complaints that received an initial response within four calendar days)
Bylaw calls for service resolved through education and voluntary compliance (per cent)
Story behind the number: The service has responded to evolving needs of Calgarians by adapting existing strategies for engagement, education and enforcement practices. Emphasizing "education before enforcement" has resulted in high compliance rates. Community safety peace officers attended 2,983 calls from 311 to ensure compliance with water use restrictions during the water feeder main emergency.

Performance Measure Name: Satisfaction with the job The City is doing providing Bylaw Education & Compliance service (per cent of Calgarians satisfied)
Average response time to priority one 3-1-1 calls by bylaw officers (hours)
Number of derelict or abandoned properties demolished or remediated
Story behind the number: The Coordinated Safety Response Team (Problem Properties Team) continues to achieve positive outcomes in communities, with 13 properties demolished this year. As the team expands, the service remains committed to developing and maintaining an established response and monitoring program to address the wide range of problem properties, aiming to meet the expected performance targets for 2026.

Performance Measure Name: Number of responses to encampment sites
Story behind the number: Since January, there have been 4,121 responses to encampment sites by peace officers, including subsequent visits, representing a 30 per cent increase in complaints and 25 per cent increase in responses compared to the same period in 2023. Addressing encampments necessitates a collaborative effort between the Encampment Team and support services. Through this coordination, peace officers uphold public safety and safeguard the unhoused community.

Performance Measure Name: Initial 9-1-1 calls answered within 15 seconds (per cent)
Story behind the number: The service continues to meet or exceed the target but strives to continuously improve this metric through training and technology and policy enhancements. This metric stems from the Alberta 9-1-1 Standard to provide prompt and reliable answering of emergency calls to benefit customers and resolve their emergency situations as promptly as possible.

Performance Measure Name: Police 9-1-1 calls answered within 15 seconds (per cent)
Story behind the number: Calgary 9-1-1 has been working to improve its performance on police call answer time to reduce the number of citizens, calling 9-1-1 with a police emergency, waiting on the line longer than 15 seconds. These initiatives include recruitment of new police call-taking staff as approved in the new 2023-2026 budget and continuous improvement of internal policies and practices.

Performance Measure Name: Satisfaction with the job The City is doing in providing 9-1-1 services (per cent of Calgarians satisfied)
Story behind the number: Calgary 9-1-1 has seen a 7 per cent increase in citizen satisfaction over 2023. Calgary 9-1-1 has addressed some past challenges that impact this metric through ongoing recruitment, staff training and efforts to reduce call wait times. The service also conducted a successful social media campaign to increase public awareness and understanding of the 9-1-1 service and continues to engage and educate the public at community events, school visits and other outreach activities.

Performance Measure Name: Average answer time for Police non-emergency calls (minutes)
Story behind the number:
The service is committed to providing timely service for both emergency and non-emergency calls. To enhance the quality of service, Calgary 9-1-1 is focusing on recruiting qualified staff and continuously improving processes and technology.  
 
Calgary is assessing the need to adjust the future performance target for Police non-emergency call answer time. As part of this research, Calgary 9-1-1, in collaboration with Calgary Police Service, is surveying other Canadian 9-1-1 centers to gather information to be able to compare its targets and operational practices for non-emergency call-answering.

Performance Measure Name: Number of emergency call transfers to the 2-1-1 Distress Centre
Story behind the number: Calgary 9-1-1 successfully transferred 1499 emergency calls to the 2-1-1 Distress Centre. The reallocation of 211 to the 911 call center has enhanced collaboration among communication officers and accelerated call transfers. This achievement is highly impactful to the population experiencing vulnerabilities and callers in crisis, who benefit from being connected to the right resource and service.

Performance Measure Name: Participation in decision-making (per cent of Calgarians that say The City allows them to have meaningful input into decision-making)
Story behind the number: This service provides City decision-makers with diverse perspectives from Calgarians. After a significant decline from the spring 2023 survey, perceptions of how well The City is meeting expectations for participation in decision-making has increased to 53 per cent in spring 2024 (up two percentage points from fall 2023). Despite being on par with municipal benchmarks, the current trend of declining public trust will impact the service's ability to meet the expected future performance of 63 per cent. The focus remains on providing Calgarians with inclusive and accessible opportunities for input into City programs and services.

Performance Measure Name: Research contribution (per cent of customers who indicate research results contributed to decision-making)
Engagement projects that report back to participants on how input was used (per cent)
Engagement participants who indicate that the engagement gave them the chance to provide input on issues or decisions that are important to them (per cent)
Opportunities for input (per cent of Calgarians who agree they have enough opportunities to provide input into decision-making about City projects and services)
Story behind the number: Calgarians expect sufficient opportunities for input in City decision-making. Perceptions about input opportunities rose slightly to 56 per cent in spring 2024 (up four percentage points from fall 2023), but remains below the 63 per cent in spring 2023. Despite surpassing the municipal benchmark for input opportunities, the diminishing trust in government makes it unlikely to meet the expected future performance of 65 per cent. The service remains committed to meeting the growing expectations of Calgarians by providing more input opportunities in 2024.

Performance Measure Name: 311 Satisfaction (per cent of Calgarians satisfied with the 311 service)
Story behind the number: High satisfaction with The City’s 311 service is crucial for maintaining customer trust. In 2024, 90 per cent of respondents expressed satisfaction with the 311 service, marking the highest score since 2021 and underscoring 311's status as a key strength of The City, where both importance and satisfaction are high. Enhancements introduced at the end of 2023, such as a call-back feature, an on-call agent pool, and a new quality assurance program, have reduced wait times and contributed positively to overall satisfaction with the 311 service.

Performance Measure Name: Calgary.ca Satisfaction (per cent of Calgarians satisfied with the City of Calgary website)
Story behind the number: Satisfaction with Calgary.ca depends on easy and reliable access to online information and services. The Spring Survey of Calgarians shows high satisfaction with The City's primary communications channel, with 84 per cent of respondents viewing Calgary.ca positively. This is the highest score since 2020, reflecting an upward trend in public perception and aligning with recent capital investments in the service. The service plans to deliver innovative, customer-centric projects throughout the business cycle, ensuring continued access to information and services for Calgarians to complete their tasks online.

Performance Measure Name: Telephone Service Factor (per cent of calls answered in 60 seconds or less)
Calls Abandoned (per cent of customers who chose to hang up before reaching a 311 agent)
Maturity in User Experience Consulting (per cent of new web projects that include User Experience consulting)
City of Calgary Credit Rating
Story behind the number: We continue to have one of the best municipal credit ratings in Canada. The City maintained its AA+ and AA (high) ratings with S&P Global Ratings and Morningstar DBRS respectively, with strong financial management practices and proven capacity to enact prudent fiscal policies and plans to respond to external risks cited as key contributors

Performance Measure Name: Total Interments
Story behind the number: This measure represents annual burial plot, cremation and mausoleum interments. The 2024 mid-year value of 679 interments reflects the total number of interments from January to June. This result is lower than previous years for the same period. The supply of casket burials at Queen’s Park Cemetery has diminished. There is more burial space are available at Prairie Sky Cemetery, but there has been a slow uptake at this location. To elevate public awareness of options at Prairie Sky Cemetery, the service has increased marketing efforts and provides alternative interment products such as green burials.

Performance Measure Name: Cemetery Interment Revenue (thousands of dollars)
Story behind the number: This measure captures annual burial plot, cremation and mausoleum interment revenues. In 2022, revenue exceeded projections after negative and inflationary impacts affected revenue in 2020 and 2021. The 2024 mid-year revenue was $676,000, which was higher than the 2023 mid-year value of $603,000. A gradual increase in revenue was expected as prices have incrementally increased due to market and inflation. Overall, revenues have been impacted by the loss of inventory at Queen’s Park Cemetery. The service is planning for the gradual growth of interments at Prairie Sky Cemetery through marketing efforts and diversified product selection.

Performance Measure Name: Perpetual Care Fund Total (thousands of dollars)
Eco-Friendly Interments
Story behind the number: Green burials were introduced in 2021 and are an interment option at Prairie Sky Cemetery. Green burials offer a dignified option and minimize environmental impacts by preserving habitat and reducing carbon emissions. Green burials are located in a natural area at the cemetery, and feature the use of non-toxic and biodegradable materials, such as ecofriendly caskets and burial shrouds. At mid-year, there were 3 eco-friendly interments. This has met our goal for mid-year.

Performance Measure Name: Income-Assisted Interments
Story behind the number: City Cemeteries operates under a not-for-profit business model. We offer a wide variety of dignified, value-based services and pricing options for all Calgarians. In addition, City Cemeteries provides services to customers in financial constraints who may not be able to afford interment services provided by private cemetery providers. This measure shows the number of customers participating in Provincially sponsored Social Assistance Programs that The City interment spaces to at reduced rates. At mid-year, there were 44 income-assisted interments, which has exceeded our expectations.

Performance Measure Name: Downtown Surplus Office Inventory Reduction (million sq ft)
Story behind the number:
Square footage reduced is the anticipated amount of vacant office space being converted from office to residential use as indicated in plans associated with project applications. Final confirmation of square footage would occur at project completion/building occupancy. 

To-date, 12 projects have been approved through the Downtown Calgary Development Inventive Program, creating over 1,556 new homes and removing approximately 1.67 million square feet of vacant office space.

Performance Measure Name: Calgarians living in communities where a modernized Local Area Plan has been recommended to Council for approval (per cent)
Story behind the number: Five Local Area Plans (LAPs) are underway in 2024, covering 46 communities and three industrial areas. The East Calgary International Avenue Communities (formerly the Greater Forest Lawn LAP) and Riley Communities LAPs are on track to be delivered to Council for consideration by Q4 2024, and will add 13 communities and two industrial areas to the total inventory of communities with modernized LAPs.

Performance Measure Name: Land area where middle density housing is allowed, per 100,000 Calgarians (hectares)
Story behind the number:
Due to consecutive years of strong migration, the rate of Calgary’s population growth was outpacing the rate of middle density zoning availability. The supply of land area where middle density housing is allowed has struggled to keep up with rising demand. 

In May 2024, Council approved Rezoning for Housing, rezoning low density residential parcels to enable middle density development and allow for more housing options in communities across the city. Implementation of the rezoning to a base residential district is scheduled for August 6, 2024, though the impact of these changes will require time to be realized.

Performance Measure Name: Land area designated for industrial uses, per 100,000 Calgarians (hectares)
Story behind the number:
Industrial development faces conversion pressures from non-industrial uses, including proposals for residential, due to airport vicinity legislation changes. Higher costs compared to neighbouring municipalities have also challenged industrial development. To address this, the 2023 Industrial Action Plan includes initiatives to enable industrial growth by updating the policy and regulatory environment, exploring financial incentives and identifying strategic considerations when land use conversions are proposed.

A reliable value for 2022 could not be provided due to an error in land use data. The 2023 value has been recalculated for accuracy.

Performance Measure Name: Serviced land supply for new communities (hectares)
Story behind the number:
Serviced land is vacant land that has an Area Structure Plan and infrastructure for transportation, water, sanitary, storm and emergency service, making it ready for development.

The reduction of serviced land supply in 2024 reflects accelerated absorption in new communities. Based on growth expectations, the current inventory of serviced land represents land supply which is above the Municipal Development Plan's target of 3-5 years of serviced land supply.

Improvements to data analysis in 2022 resulted in land supply data being available for the same year it is reported instead of the year prior, so no land supply data was produced in 2021

Performance Measure Name: Environmentally Significant Area protected and conserved in greenfield development (per cent of ESA protected or restored calculated at land use amendment/outline plan approval)
Number of sites assessed annually - Contaminated Site Management
Story behind the number: Mid year 2024, 600 sites have been assessed for contamination. This is consistent with the number of sites assessed for contamination mid year 2023.

Performance Measure Name: Number of properties within 1:100 River Flood Extent - Flood Exposure Risk
Tracking Adaptation and Measuring Development (TAMD) Scorecard (rating)
Measured amount of carbon dioxide (CO2) equivalent (e) released - Corporate Greenhouse Gas Emissions (1,000 tonnes CO2e (kilotonnes))
Story behind the number: Market-based corporate greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions have been below 2005 baseline levels since 2012, when The City began procuring Renewable Energy Certificates (RECs) to offset electricity consumption. 2023 Market-based Corporate GHG emissions are 42 per cent lower than 2005 levels. Several projects were initiated to reduce GHGs (updated Sustainable Building Policy, Business Unit GHG Reduction Plans & the Centralized Climate Fund). In 2024, The City completed a second-party review of its GHG emissions inventory and updated its methodology and emissions factors with the most recent National Inventory Report to enhance reporting accuracy. This review resulted in updates to the 2005 baseline value, historically reported emissions values and the 2026 target, which resulted in changes to this metric.

Performance Measure Name: Partners, collaborators and advisory board members who agree that Community Strategies is helping prevent social and community issues (per cent).
Partners, collaborators and advisory board members who agree that Community Strategies is helping to remove barriers to participation in civic life (per cent).
Agreement that the Anti-Racism Action Strategy is impactful in removing systemic racism (per cent).
Story behind the number: The existing performance measure was developed in 2022 as a placeholder, prior to the launch of the Anti-Racism Strategic Plan and Framework, and data has not been collected on it. Instead, quarterly updates were provided directly to Council on the Anti-Racism Program.  A replacement performance measure will be brought to Council for approval at the 2024 Mid-Cycle Budget Adjustments, to better align to current focus areas within the Anti-Racism Strategic Plan.

Performance Measure Name: Financial Empowerment program participants that report being less stressed about their financial situation than they were a year ago (per cent).
Social inclusion program participants that report feeling they have someone to enjoy their time with compared to a year ago (per cent).
Story behind the number: A sense of social connection among residents is critical to a socially resilient Calgary. It is also an outcome area of Family and Community Support Services (FCSS) programs. This measure compares responses of FCSS program participants before and after program completion. Based on data that funded organizations have shared for the first six months of 2024, we estimate that feelings of social isolation have declined for a significant number of post-program participants.

Performance Measure Name: Policies up to date (per cent)
Story behind the number: Interpretation of the up-to-date policy measure has been adjusted for 2024. Only policies that have completed an overall review following the Corporate process are now counted. This has resulted in reduction of Administration policies up to date as of this quarter. However, by no longer counting polices that have had a targeted change without a full review, this calculation now better demonstrates the proportion of policies that are current, relevant and responsive to current risks and opportunities. Through work currently in progress, this measure is still expected to achieve its 2026 target. of 70% of policies up-to-date.

Performance Measure Name: Businesses Supported by Business and Local Economy (BLE)
Story behind the number: Other than Digital Service Squad, most of the rest of our work during the last six months involved indirect assistance to businesses. We have served 424 businesses directly through that program this year (completed service plans). We have also presented to many entrepreneurs through Build your Business programs offered by community partners such as Calgary Catholic Immigration Services.

Performance Measure Name: Respondents who answer favorably about whether they consider The City to be "business-friendly" (per cent)
Story behind the number: In the latest Business Perspectives Panel survey (end of 2024), 33 per cent of respondents said that The City supported a positive business environment citing "lack of vision" "high taxes" and "social disorder" as barriers to improving the business environment.

Performance Measure Name: City and community participants who report being better able to understand and/or apply resilient qualities or futures thinking to their work (per cent)
Story behind the number:
Strategic Foresight methodology offers a powerful toolkit for de-risking strategy against future disruptions, ensuring a more resilient and sustainable City. The training and workshops offered since January 2024 resulted in 86 per cent of participants feeling that the insights and tools acquired are useful for their work, with 81 per cent leaving the sessions with a strong understanding of how they will apply the new information.  

Furthermore, 81 per cent of participants felt that the training/workshop helped facilitate new ideas about possible futures which, in turn, will foster greater resilience for The City and Calgarians.

Performance Measure Name: Professional members who have completed Professional Practice Management Plan training within the past 2 years (per cent)
Story behind the number: The City has gone from about 70 per cent compliance to 90.7 per cent compliance in the last 4 quarters.

Performance Measure Name: Number of threat risk assessments and security consultations conducted by year
Story behind the number: Corporate Security assesses threats and consults on security matters to proactively identify and mitigate risks throughout the corporation. This year, 288 threat risk assessments and security consultations related to physical security, cyber security, events, and employees have been conducted. A dedicated resource for this work has led to a notable rise in the amount of physical security threat risk assessments. Employee support services have reduced by about half compared to the same period last year. The reduction may be related to the training and education that staff receive on situational awareness and how to safeguard themselves.

Performance Measure Name: Number of incidents including social disorder
Story behind the number: In the first five months of 2024, the number of incidents related to social disorder have slightly decreased compared to previous years. Regardless, 673 incidents speak to the ongoing presence of social disorder in and around City sites. Corporate Security closely monitors this measure to maintain a safe and secure environment for its employees and the citizens of Calgary.

Performance Measure Name: Number of security responses to distress
Story behind the number: Corporate Security responds to distressing situations that involve administering First Aid, managing mental health emergencies and drug poisonings, which can lead to the use of Naloxone. Corporate Security continues to patrol LRT stations, an expansion that commenced in October of 2022.

Performance Measure Name: Number of security education sessions delivered
Story behind the number: This mid-year value has already surpassed the total number of security education sessions delivered in 2023. Reasons for this increase may include security incidents observed by employees, employee interactions with members of the public and work areas proactively training their public facing staff. Also, an increasing awareness that Corporate Security provides this service may have contributed to this rise.

Performance Measure Name: Number of investigations - policy breaches
Story behind the number: Corporate Security investigates allegations of Corporate Administration Policy breaches. The main policies investigated from January to end of May 2024 were the Labour Relations policy and the Workplace Violence Prevention policy. Corporate Security continues to collaborate with Labour Relations, Human Resources and Law to identify policy breaches and address their underlying causes.

Performance Measure Name: Number of recognition and protocol activities per year
Story behind the number:
Demand for protocol activities and services has remained steady for the first half of 2024.

The City Clerk’s Office continues to support requests for flag raisings, courtesy calls and delegation visits, letters of recognition and proclamations and opening remarks for the Mayor or Deputy Mayor.

The Calgary Awards were successfully delivered in June.

In 2024, the Municipal Complex tour program and Quebec City/Calgary exchange program are undergoing review and improvement opportunities.

Performance Measure Name: Accurate and on-time Council and Council Committee minutes publication rate (per cent)
Story behind the number: Out of the 65 Council and Committee meeting minutes that were published, 4 sets of minutes were published late or had minor clerical corrections.

Performance Measure Name: Hours of Council and Council Committee Meetings (hours per month)
Story behind the number:
The number of Council and Council Committee meetings has continued at a steady rate. 

The 2024 April 22 Public Hearing Meeting of Council on citywide rezoning was the largest public hearing in the City’s history and impacted the overall hours of Council and Committee Meetings being reported at mid-year.

Performance Measure Name: Applicants who self-identify as a member of a minority group (per cent)
Story behind the number: Not reported at mid-year

Performance Measure Name: Boards, Commissions and Committees' leadership's rate of satisfaction with governance support (per cent)
Story behind the number: Not reported at mid-year.

Performance Measure Name: Annual number of mapping product views on calgary.ca - Web Mapping Views
Story behind the number: Beginning in 2024, view counts encompassed all publicly accessible maps, including featured mapping products on calgary.ca that utilize feature services managed by Geospatial Business Solutions (GBS). Additionally, views exceeded expectations due to increased viewership of traffic-related maps during weather events.

Performance Measure Name: Number of City employees accessing GIS data and mapping products - GIS Technology Adoption
Story behind the number: During the first half of this year, there was an increase in the number of users accessing Geographic Information System (GIS) data. It is anticipated that this trend will continue, surpassing the year-end target. This growth can be attributed to the promotion of self-serve employee tools and a broader organizational shift toward leveraging technology for operational efficiencies and data-driven decision-making. This is especially evident in areas that directly support planning services through use of GIS applications including the City-wide rezoning map, Development map (D-Map) and Local Policy Plan maps.

Performance Measure Name: Base Map Updates - registered survey plans that are mapped within 21 days of receipt (per cent)
Story behind the number: In 2024, the workload for this aspect of our operations remained consistent with the increased workload observed in 2023. Other areas of our operations also experienced heightened activity, including a greater volume of tentative plans, address management, and mapping of building footprints for new construction. However, due to this substantial increase in workload, the base mapping staff faced challenges in maintaining operational efficiency and meeting processing targets.

Performance Measure Name: Addressing Updates - external addressing service requests resolved within 10 days of receipt (per cent)
Story behind the number:
The lower-than-expected performance can be attributed to increased workloads resulting from new developments and redevelopments. Between June 2023 and June 2024, job volume rose by 41 per cent, even more significant considering the record 56 per cent increase in 2023. Additionally, the increase in number of online systems relying on addressing information led to extensive triage for suspected invalid addresses, causing address validation delays.

As a result of these challenges, staffing remains an issue due to the workload surge. Limited-term staffing ensures service continuity.

Performance Measure Name: Number of open data sets available on Open Calgary Portal
Story behind the number: The increase in the number of available datasets corresponds to the capacity of our current Open Data Strategist resource. As we expand our team in this area, we anticipate an even larger increase of available datasets.

Performance Measure Name: Significant development proposals that  have a Good or Excellent urban design rating at  the time of approval (per cent)
Civil engineering designs approved with one or no revisions (per cent)
Technical development applications where decision timelines were met (per cent)
Story behind the number: Technical development application volumes have increased during the first half of 2024 compared to 2023. We continue to see strong decision performance at 83% year to date. Technical Planning leverages team experience to move files through the application process quickly while acting as subject matter experts on process improvement and technological initiatives to benefit both customers and staff.

Performance Measure Name: Multidisciplinary development applications where decision timeline commitments were met (per cent)
Story behind the number: Increased volumes and complexity of applications have continued to challenge the planning and engineering teams reviewing multidisciplinary applications. At 78% on-time decision performance, this metric sits below our targeted commitment of 85%. Ongoing hiring efforts along with retention and engagement strategies pave the way for increased performance in the coming months. Staff remain committed to their work and our customers while making all efforts to balance workloads.

Performance Measure Name: Average customer satisfaction from post-application surveys (per cent)
Number of Direct Jobs created/retained/expanded (Collected by Calgary Economic Development)
Story behind the number: Tech is flourishing in Calgary including Amazon’s recent investment of more than $400 million in fulfillment centres that created 1,500 new jobs. Fortinet’s new Calgary headquarters created 165 new jobs and reinforced Calgary as a centre of excellence in fintech and cyber security. UK-based Achilles and Veripark have also recently made Calgary their North American and Canadian hubs, respectively. Calgary Economic Development’s (CED) focus on South Korea as a key market, supported by WestJet’s recently launched Calgary-Seoul flight, is paying off with Bore Da Biotech marking CED’s first life sciences investment from South Korea.

Performance Measure Name: Economic impact of TELUS Convention Centre delegates (Provided by the Calgary Convention Centre Authority) (millions of dollars)
Story behind the number: The Calgary TELUS Convention Centre hosted 92 events with 66,742 delegates, generating $23.9 million in total direct economic impact for Calgary, meeting the organization’s 2023 target already by mid-year. The total economic impact to date is $50.7 million - $23.9 million direct impact, $16.6 million indirect impact and $10.1 million induced impact. Direct economic impact is spending tied to the delegates specifically. Indirect and induced impact is related to spending by businesses that are affected by the meetings and conventions at the facility. The organization is on pace to meet or exceed the total economic impact in 2023.

Performance Measure Name: Number of innovation driven startups that transition to five employees or more in a year
Cultural Attraction Attendance (millions)
Leverage ratio of funds contributed by Partners to support program and service delivery
City services that are compliant with corporate business continuity policy (per cent)
Story behind the number: This measures the service’s role in coordinating corporate business continuity planning activities. The target was set to align with the Business Continuity Planning administrative policy which focuses on maintaining 100 per cent compliance. The service completed its annual compliance reporting for the Business Continuity Program during Q1/Q2. For 2023, 31 out of 34 business units complied with the policy. The service is working with the non-compliant business units with the goal of achieving compliance by year end.

Performance Measure Name: Participants who completed emergency preparedness programming who feel more prepared for emergencies (per cent)
Story behind the number: This measures the service’s role in preparing the community for emergencies and the service continues to meet the target. The target is based on historic baseline data and the focus is on maintaining a high standard while continuing to expand access to programming. For Q1/Q2, over 1,100 people have accessed the service’s e-courses with 92 per cent of survey respondents feeling more prepared upon completion.

Performance Measure Name: Agency members who feel confident in their ability to fill their role if called to the Emergency Operations Centre (per cent)
Agency members who are satisfied in the leadership provided to the Calgary Emergency Management Agency (per cent)
Agency members who are confident in their understanding of local disaster risks (per cent)
City of Calgary Credit Rating
Story behind the number: The City's AA+ credit rating did not change during this reporting period. As noted in the previous update, Calgary's AA+ credit rating is the strongest for municipalities in Alberta.

Performance Measure Name: Calgarians who trust in The City of Calgary (per cent)
Story behind the number: The 2024 Spring Survey of Calgarians revealed an eleven-point drop in this metric from the previous Fall Survey. Like other municipalities, Calgary continues to experience decreasing levels of resident trust tied to political polarization and economic issues. These results are also consistent with global trends related to the erosion of social cohesion and misinformation. Executive Leadership continues to monitor these developments and is enhancing its messaging to Calgarians to improve resident and business understanding of The City's service delivery, programs, and actions.

Performance Measure Name: Calgarians with positive perceptions of the value of property taxes (per cent)
Story behind the number: Calgarians' perception of value from property taxes dropped by six percent since the Fall Survey. The main factor driving this change appears to be driven by economic factors. Generally, Calgarians who state they have a good quality of life and are satisfied with The City's services and programs are more likely to report that have received good value from their tax dollars. This highlights the importance of customer service and meeting residents' service expectation. Accordingly, Executive Leadership continues to focus on strengthening the organization's culture with a focus on customer service and service excellence.

Performance Measure Name: Employee Engagement Index
Story behind the number: The next employee engagement results will be released Fall 2025. Executive Leadership continues to focus on strengthening The City's culture and leadership practice, as required to modernize municipal government and adapt to the rapidly changing political, economic, and social environment.

Performance Measure Name: Calgarians’ satisfaction with how Administration and Council runs the city (per cent)
Story behind the number: TThe working relationship between Council and Administration is a driver of trust for Calgarians. This metric has dropped four percentage points since the Fall 2023 Survey of Calgarians and is fourteen points lower from its peak of 72 percent in late 2021 during the pandemic. Executive Leadership continues to work closely with Council to serve and support Calgarians and operate a sustainable municipal government supportive of Calgarians’ needs. External factors also contribute to negative perceptions such as economic challenges including inflation, interest rates, and food and housing affordability experienced by many cities.

Performance Measure Name: Facility Management Age Based Deferred Maintenance (millions of dollars)
Story behind the number: Age-based Deferred Maintenance has grown since 2023 due to transfer of assets through the Corporate Coordinated Operations & Maintenance (CCOM) Program and updates to decay assumptions utilized in the Enterprise Asset Management (EAM) system; the current estimate is $901.7 million. However, this deferred maintenance value has stabilized over first half of 2024 due to: 1) increased resources available to review, update and enter more building condition data, 2) a slowdown of facilities transferred through CCOM in 2024 and 3) continued investments that slow the decay rate.

Performance Measure Name: Proportion of Work Orders that are Preventative Maintenance (per cent)
Story behind the number: Despite the significant increase in facilities transferred through the Corporate Coordinated Operations & Maintenance (CCOM) program, Facilities continues to trend towards meeting its 2026 target, currently at 67 per cent Preventative Maintenance (PM) to 33 per cent on-demand (OD). To continue to achieve and maintain the targeted PM to OD ratio, Facilities has been identifying & harmonizing opportunities across the full portfolio and monitoring the on-demand cycle to identify areas of high demand that can proactively be addressed by the PM program instead.

Performance Measure Name: Facility Management Assets in Poor & Critical Condition (per cent)
Story behind the number: Facilities continues to improve data by using Building Condition Assessments (BCAs) and completing BCAs on assets transferred without prior assessments in place. The Asset Management team has completed 160 BCAs to date and are targeting to complete an additional 114 BCAs; the majority are new BCAs, but may include re-inspections. BCAs are used to prioritize investment (including the additional $20M from 2023) into assets, including 12 per cent of buildings assessed as having poor and critical components.

Performance Measure Name: Hybrid Workspace for Key Downtown Administrative Buildings (per cent)
Story behind the number: Facilities continues to look for innovative solutions to manage growing staff without growing beyond our Corporate footprint; this includes exploring new workstyles, including desk sharing, mobile stations, and other workstyles that may increase space utilization. Facilities also continues to support efficient workspace planning for existing anchored spaces, maximizing the available space to accommodate workplace needs.

Performance Measure Name: Energy Consumption per Square Meter for Office and Recreation Portfolios (GJ/SQM)
Story behind the number: Overall energy consumption at City Facilities has stabilized over the previous year across the Recreation and Office portfolios (3.0 and 1.0 Gigajoules per square metre, respectively), but are still trending downward from 2019 levels. Facilities continues to invest in improvements towards building energy efficiency and reducing energy consumption in order to meet 2026 targets.

Performance Measure Name: Total number of real estate transactions (includes sales, acquisitions, leases, licenses, utility right of way, easement, restricted covenant, option to repurchase, or any other real estate transactions)
Unmodified External Audit Opinion with no Unaddressed Audit Findings (per cent)
Story behind the number: The City strives for an unmodified opinion issued annually by the external auditor, which was achieved with no unaddressed audit findings reported again this year. This is based on audit evidence obtained about the amounts and disclosures of the financial statements which are completed competently with a focus on implementation of new Public Sector Accounting Standards.

Performance Measure Name: Invoices Paid within 30 days (per cent)
Story behind the number: Accounts Payable’s standard is to pay invoices on time and not within a set number of days.  While a payment term of 30 days is common, there are often other payment terms attached to invoices. Per cent of invoices paid within 30 days should be viewed as a guide to the magnitude and direction of timely payments made by Accounts Payable but it does not completely reflect The City’s commitment to timely payment.

Performance Measure Name: Bad debt write-off as a per cent of billed revenue (per cent)
Story behind the number:
The collaborative and solutions-focused approach to managing financial and reputational risk associated with outstanding corporate receivables continues to be effective.   
As of 2024 June 30, total write-offs of approximately $122 thousand were recognized against total billed revenue of approximately $223.7 million.

Performance Measure Name: Accounts Payable Operating Cost per Invoice Processed (dollars)
Story behind the number: Performance results for accounts payable remain consistent with those of recent years.  While there are minor variations from year-to-year, the results continue to reflect accounts payable’s ongoing commitment to efficient processing with existing resources while managing the increasing volume of payments to The City’s partners in our community.

Performance Measure Name: First-in engine emergency responses within seven minutes to fire incidents (per cent time target is achieved)
Story behind the number: From January to May, overall performance of first-in engine emergency response time remains relatively consistent despite an increased volume of 381 first-in engine responses to fire emergencies compared to the same period last year. First-in engines arrive at fires within seven minutes and 44 seconds 90 per cent of the time. The service is examining short and long-term strategies to improve this metric, including reinstating a medical response unit at Station 2 to enable the first-in engines to just focus on fire incidents.

Performance Measure Name: Arrival of two engines, one aerial unit and a minimum of 12 firefighters within 11 minutes at serious and escalating fires (per cent time target is achieved)
Story behind the number: Arrival times of critical resources to serious and escalating fires has decreased by 7.5 per cent as compared to the same period last year (January to May). The 90th percentile response time for arriving at these incidents is 13 minutes and 57 seconds. It is important to note that due to the relatively small volume of serious and escalating fires there is a significant variation in the 90th percentile statistic for this measure. The service will increase staffing on aerial units in 2025 and 2026 to support improved performance and will analyze the impact to the measure due to new community growth.

Performance Measure Name: Flame spread limited to within the room or object of origin (per cent time achieved)
Story behind the number: From January to May, the service exceeded the target of 67 per cent, demonstrating improved containment of flame spread to within the room or object of origin compared to the same period last year. Flame spread is influenced by various factors, including fire type, location, structural design, safety systems and preventive measures.

Performance Measure Name: First-in unit emergency responses within six minutes thirty seconds at critical medical incidents (per cent time target is achieved)
Story behind the number: First-in unit response time has declined by 5 per cent over the same period as last year (January to May) and the 90th percentile response time is 21 seconds longer. The number of critical medical incidents are historically elevated but have decreased by 12 per cent compared to the same period last year. The call dispatch time for critical medical incidents has increased by 10 seconds compared to the same period in 2023 and it is 26 seconds more than the benchmark time of 30 seconds. The service is working with Calgary 911 to identify root cause.

Performance Measure Name: Number of Calgarians engaged in fire prevention and life safety education by firefighters
Story behind the number: The service continues to educate Calgarians through various programs, including School Fire Drills and Station Tours requested through 311. So far from January to May, 5,301 Calgarians visited fire stations for tours, averaging 20 visitors per tour. Key engagement programs such as the Home Safety Program and Fire Safety Reports will start later in the year. The service is also exploring opportunities to enhance Fire Safety Education programs to target vulnerable populations.

Performance Measure Name: Number of fire safety inspections performed by Inspectors
Story behind the number: From January to May, the service experienced a 25 per cent increase in demand for inspections due to the increasing volume of high-risk occupancies, citizen complaints and requests and inquiries compared to the same period last year. The service continues to observe an increased demand for inspections and it is projected to conduct more than the targeted 18,000 inspections by the year end.

Performance Measure Name: 3-1-1 Customer Service Requests completed on time (per cent)
Story behind the number: From January to May, the service completed 88 per cent of inspections on time but performance is 10 per cent lower than in the same period last year. The service continues to observe complex issues in residential high-risk occupancy groups (i.e., secondary suites) that are resulting in more violations and these are taking longer to complete resulting in an open 311 service request until such time that all the violations are resolved by the customer. The service is exploring optimizing this measure to accurately report on service response as compared to the number of re-inspections.

Performance Measure Name: Reduction in fire risk level for inspectable properties citywide (per cent)
Story behind the number: The service reduced the fire risk level for inspectable properties (January to May). A new parameter capturing the risk for residential occupancies was included in 2023, resulting in an increase in the fire risk level for inspectable properties. The 2023 year-end measure changed from -1.6 to -3.6 due to increased risk across these inspectable properties and resulted in certain properties being prioritized for inspection. As a result, the service is working through a large volume of high-risk inspections.

Performance Measure Name: Re-inspection ratio (per cent)
Story behind the number: The service experienced an increase compared to the same period last year (January to May), which is attributed to increasing complexity of violations in high-risk occupancies. This is due to the length of time that certain properties have not completed an inspection and results in a higher volume of code violations. The service plans to engage and educate all customers and determine strategies to reduce re-inspections.

Performance Measure Name: Number of structure fires in commercial/Industrial/multi-family occupancies
Story behind the number: The number of fires in inspectable properties, including commercial, industrial and multi-family occupancies, increased compared to 69 fires in the same period last year (January to May). Approximately 68 per cent of structure fires happen in multi-family occupancies whereas structure fires in commercial and industrial occupancies make up a smaller proportion and are trending downwards. The service is exploring delivery models that will enable expansion and enhancement of its prevention inspection program offerings to further reduce community risks, especially with a focus on multi-family occupancies.

Performance Measure Name: Number of Calgarians contacted annually about fire prevention and life safety through non-emergency initiatives
Story behind the number: The service contacted 30 per cent more Calgarians compared to the same period last year (January to May). The service continues to focus on in-person engagements and is challenged to meet targets due to capacity limitations. The service is exploring other channels such as social and digital media to deliver programming that better serves the community's needs.

Performance Measure Name: Number of Calgarians experiencing vulnerabilities that receive fire safety education
Story behind the number: From January to May, the service provided a modest increase in fire and life safety education to individuals experiencing vulnerabilities as compared to 2023. The addition of a new public education officer supported the achievement of this result. As the population of individuals experiencing vulnerabilities is expected to increase, the service is exploring alternate methods of delivering education services.

Performance Measure Name: Calgarians that believe they are prepared and have a plan to deal with a fire emergency (per cent)
Contacts who feel safer and better equipped with fire and life safety information after receiving education (per cent)
Story behind the number: From January to May, 88 per cent of participants in the School Fire Drill Program reported feeling safer and better equipped with fire and life safety information after receiving education. The service is performing above its target and will continue to use community risk data to identify fire and life safety risks. The service will continue to tailor its program to target specific demographics across Calgary based on the fire and life safety risks of a particular community.

Performance Measure Name: Communities in Calgary exceeding the community fire risk threshold (per cent)
Carrier Profile Risk Factor (calculation using collisions, convictions, and inspections) (rating)
Story behind the number: The mid-year Carrier Profile Risk Factor is 0.182, down from the January 2024 value of 0.214.  The City is now in Stage 1 monitoring (down from Stage 3 in Q1 2024). This reflects the positive impact of ongoing risk management initiatives and the changes in the risk factor scoring process that were implemented to improve the carrier profile's risk monitory. The service will continue to manage risk and focus on improving driver behaviour to move out of provincial monitoring in 2024.

Performance Measure Name: Maintenance labour hours spent on unplanned jobs - Fix-on-Fail Jobs (per cent)
Story behind the number:
So far in 2024, 31.7 per cent of time has been spent on work for unexpected vehicle breakdowns, which is slightly higher than the target. The City's aim is to provide preventative maintenance that reduces unexpected breakdowns, allowing consistent and predictable services to be delivered to citizens.

The 2024 average percentage of fix-on-fail jobs is above the targeted maximum as there continue to be delays in receiving new replacement units. A third of the fleet is beyond prime economic life, an increase from 2023, leading to more unexpected breakdowns. There have also been warranty issues with new side-load refuse trucks.

Performance Measure Name: Underutilized Light-Duty Fleet (per cent)
Story behind the number: By mid-year 2024, 21.4 per cent of light-duty fleet vehicles in prime life were underutilized (i.e., driven less than 7,500 km and used fewer than 125 days). This is almost the same as the per cent calculated at the end of 2023 and an improvement from the previous years (24 per cent in 2020 and 22 per cent in 2021). The impact of light-duty vehicles that moved over to Fleet Management from other business units (i.e., Calgary Parking Authority, Calgary Transit) following corporate realignment must still be fully realized. The target is 15 per cent by the end of 2026.

Performance Measure Name: Total Fuel Consumed by Light-Duty Vehicles (Litres per 100 km)
Story behind the number: By the end of June, the fuel liters used per 100 kilometers were trending downward, with 15.6 L/100 km used. This is an improvement from 2023 (17.3 L/100 km) and has surpassed the 2026 target of 17 L/100 km.  This decrease is a result of multiple initiatives, such as The City's idling reduction program and green driving program, which have proven effective. Since 2020, year-over-year idling for corporate fleet vehicles has steadily decreased.

Performance Measure Name: Fleet-Owned Vehicles that are Green (per cent)
Story behind the number: As of mid-year 2024, 5.5 percent of Fleet-owned vehicles are either battery electric (43) or hybrid (89), meeting the business cycle target. Compared to the end of 2023, when the value was 4.8 percent, Fleet has acquired 20 additional hybrid units. Fleet Management is making progress toward modernizing and greening the municipal fleet in support of the Green Fleet Program and corporate climate mitigation efforts.

Performance Measure Name: Leadership Impact Index
Story behind the number: Data for this measure is from the biennial Corporate Employee Survey. The 2023 performance index for Leadership Impact suggests that the organization has made some progress in supporting increased leadership accountability, employee empowerment, culture, and employee engagement. Focusing on creating a more inclusive, respectful and accountable workplace culture continues to be a key corporate and Human Resources Support priority.

Performance Measure Name: Employee Engagement Index
Story behind the number: Data for this measure is from the biennial Corporate Employee Survey. The 2023 performance index for Employee Engagement suggests that the organization has made some progress in supporting increased employee engagement. Focusing on creating a more inclusive, respectful and accountable workplace culture continues to be a key corporate and Human Resources Support priority.

Performance Measure Name: Inclusion Index
Story behind the number: Data for this measure is from the biennial Corporate Employee Survey. The 2023 performance index for Inclusion suggests that the organization has made some progress in addressing issues of reconciliation, human rights, anti-racism, equity, diversity and inclusion. Focusing on creating a more inclusive, respectful and accountable workplace culture continues to be a key corporate and Human Resources Support priority.

Performance Measure Name: Employee voluntary turnover rate (per cent)
Story behind the number: In the first half of 2024, the voluntary turnover rate (resignations + retirements) for City Administration was 2.0 per cent, the lowest compared to the same period in the last five years. While there is a slight upward trend in employee resignations, due to the growth in the headcount the rate remains stable. Retirements have remained stable since 2022 at The City, with the annual rates of 2.0 per cent and 2.1 per cent, 2022 and 2023 respectively, which align with industry standards, as per Conference Board of Canada Benchmarking.

Performance Measure Name: Human Resources Voluntary Turnover Rate (per cent)
Story behind the number: In the first half of 2024, the voluntary turnover rate for Human Resources was 1.5 per cent, the lowest compared to the same period in the last five years (which was in between 5.6 in 2023 and 11.3 in 2021). Voluntary turnover year to date was solely driven by retirements.

Performance Measure Name: Asset-intensive service lines with completed maturity assessment (per cent)
Story behind the number: An Asset Management Maturity Assessment has been completed for Mobility. The Maturity Assessment for Potable Water is undergoing final review. The Assessment for Wastewater is underway, and work is progressing on developing improvement strategies and plans. The Stormwater assessment has been delayed until later in the year. Although some assessments have proceeded slower than expected, primarily due to resource constraints and the response to the Bearspaw South feeder main break, we still expect to achieve our goal by the end of 2026.

Performance Measure Name: Number of completed Value Management studies
Story behind the number:
In 2024, we completed one Value Management Study for Richmond Green Park by Parks and Open Spaces to ensure it achieves its objectives in the most efficient and effective manner. Key outcomes of the Richmond Green Park Study include adjustment of initial cost estimates for contractor markups and inflation rates, aligning the project with its budget, potential savings of approximately $2M identified from the original $25M estimate, and generation of numerous ideas to improve the park's use for all Calgary residents. 

Preliminary conversation is underway for another study for Capital Priorities & Investments in Fall 2024.

Performance Measure Name: Capital managed in the corporate Project Management System (per cent)
Story behind the number: The percentage is calculated by dividing the 2024 budget of projects managed in the Project and Program Management (P2M) system by the approved total 2024 budget of the corresponding projects in the Financial & Supply Chain Management (FSCM) system. To enhance this value, we have made efforts to identify capital projects and programs that are not yet managed in P2M, collaborate with stakeholders to transition them to the P2M platform, and provide subsequent training.

Performance Measure Name: Energy used to deliver all City services, per Calgarian (megawatt hours equivalent)
Story behind the number: The latest energy per capita metric is 0.9722 MWhe (mega watt hour equivalent) per citizen. This metric is calculated based on the total energy used by The City in the most recent 12-month period with available energy data and the City's population during that time. The significant year-over-year increase in population between 2023 and 2024 is a notable driver for changes to our energy per capita metric compared to last year.

Performance Measure Name: Average time to respond to a Calgarian on a new claim (days)
Story behind the number: Through automation and service improvement initiatives, the average time to respond to a Calgarian on a new claim is now 1.8 business days. At the end of this budget cycle (2026), the target is to achieve an average time of 1 business day and we are currently progressing as planned.

Performance Measure Name: Average caseload per adjuster
Story behind the number: The decrease in the average number of files per adjuster is progressing as planned, and is trending towards 250 active files by the end of this budget cycle. The increase in reported pothole claims this year has not significantly affected progress on this measure.

Performance Measure Name: Overall Satisfaction with IT (per cent)
Story behind the number: This measure reflects IT's client satisfaction in areas such as equipment availability and reliability, response time, business support services, and new technologies that support changing business needs. Since 2016, Information Technology has maintained an overall client satisfaction value of between 91 and 92 per cent. In 2024, this value rose to an all-time high of 95 per cent.  In addition, the percentage of “Very Satisfied” respondents increased from 44 per cent in 2016 to 57 per cent in 2024.

Performance Measure Name: Number of Community Business Ideas Supported Through Living Labs
Story behind the number: To build on Calgary’s reputation as a leader in supporting innovation, The City of Calgary is currently hosting 42 active initiatives for Living Labs. These cater to a wide array of needs from businesses and researchers spanning various domains and include drone technology, Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) scanning, asset and vehicle tracking, smart furniture, noise-cancelling technology, and a range of Internet of Things applications. Living Labs is undergoing significant revisions in its processes, procedures, and metrics to enhance the consistency and reliability of the process while also improving reporting capabilities.

Performance Measure Name: IT Service Desk Phone Calls with First Contact Resolution (per cent)
Story behind the number:
First contact resolution is considered an industry standard for measuring call 
center performance. Since 2018, the rate of first contact resolution has been tracking 
between 64 and 69 per cent. This level of performance is consistent with the percentages reported by similar organizations. As the complexity of The City's technology environment increases, it is anticipated that the Service Desk will need to send more calls to other groups for resolution, which will cause the First Contact Resolution numbers to start to trend lower year-over-year.

Performance Measure Name: Number of Connections to Free Wi-Fi in Public Locations (millions)
Story behind the number: As part of The City's Public Wi-Fi program, free public Wi-Fi service is available at 79 different City locations, including all City-owned arenas, indoor pools, art centers, leisure centers, and Light Rail Transit (LRT) platforms.  Since 2014, there have been over 93 million connections to The City's free public Wi-Fi service.

Performance Measure Name: Low Powered End User Computing Devices as a Percentage of Overall Devices (per cent)
Story behind the number: With approximately 14,000 computing devices at The City, reducing power consumption results in a positive impact in support of climate resilience. Information Technology, in partnership with its hardware vendors, works to standardize technology devices that have lower power consumption and configures device settings to reduce power.  Currently, 81 per cent of The City’s computing devices are considered low wattage according to Energy Star ratings (less than 30 kilowatt-hours).

Performance Measure Name: Industrial land sales (millions of dollars)
Story behind the number: Constellation Industrial Park commenced sales on April 15, 2024. With approximately 48 acres of land available for sale in Phase 1A, negotiations with potential purchasers are advancing as planned. In addition, fully serviced lots were made available for sale at Midfield Heights in June 2024.

Performance Measure Name: Increase in assessed value from land and improvements (millions of dollars)
Number of permanent jobs created
Private capital investment (millions of dollars)
Amount of serviced industrial land available for sale (acres)
Story behind the number: With the sales launch of Constellation Industrial Park’s Phase 1A in April 2024, the supply of serviced industrial land available has been replenished by an additional 48.98 acres, with just over 64 acres of fully serviced industrial land available for sale or conditionally sold as of June 2024. The supply of serviced industrial land available for sale will continue to increase as development at Constellation progresses with future planned Phases.

Performance Measure Name: Customer Satisfaction (per cent)
Legal Services staff retained (per cent)
Story behind the number:
Law’s retention rate had a small decrease for the period January 1 – May 31, 2024. This is in part due to intentional resource allocation and business planning.

Please note that 96.1 is for the entire Business Unit, and not just Legal Services.

Performance Measure Name: Average number of short-term sickness and accident days per employee per year
Story behind the number:
Law has seen a decrease in the average number of S & A days per employee for the period January 1 – May 31, 2024. This may be attributed to our continued focus on staff wellness and engagement.

Please note that 2.8 is for the entire Business Unit, and not just Legal Services

Performance Measure Name: Legal work kept in-house annually (per cent)
Story behind the number:
The amount of work kept in-house increased from the previous year.  During the first half of 2024, external counsel continued to provide services on high priority capital matters such as Green Line and Event Centre, in addition to other matters.

Engaging external counsel is an effective tool to address capacity limitations, meet demand for legal resources where conflicts exist, ensure appropriate expertise when not available internally, and increase staff knowledge.

Performance Measure Name: On-time FOIP Access Requests Rate (per cent on-time)
Story behind the number: The increase in volume (14%), the complexity of access requests, and staff movements have impacted the capacity to process access requests; however, on-time rates have remained steady.

Performance Measure Name: Annual Library Uses Per Person
Story behind the number: As a per capita measure, this value is directly related to The City’s population growth. The value at year end 2023 was approximately 29.2. Annual Library Uses is comprised of 11 different metrics, the criteria and definition of which are developed in conjunction with other Canadian Library systems. With population growth, changes in this metric would be related to growth in Library assets, such as spaces and lending materials.

Performance Measure Name: Library Operating Cost Per Use (dollars)
Story behind the number: This measure has remained consistent with 2022 and 2023 but the goal is to reduce this number. This measure compares the Total Uses to the cost of providing those services where increases to operating costs are offset by increases in Uses. As 2024 is a collective bargaining year, this will impact final costs after the fact and this measure could be negatively impacted.

Performance Measure Name: Annual Library Visits Per Person
Story behind the number: Halfway through 2024, library visits per capita have increased 39 percent. Visits to Library buildings continue to recover from pandemic levels and have now ‘normalized’ to pre-pandemic levels. The Library anticipates that total visitations will continue to increase due to continued population growth. Like other per capita measures, population growth impacts progress on this metric.

Performance Measure Name: Percentage of Calgarians that are  Registered Cardholders
Story behind the number: Members as a Percentage of Population is another per capita measure the service strives to increase. Active members denote those who have used their Library card within the past 36 months. The Library has seen consistent membership growth over the last six quarters, comprised of both new members, and retaining existing members. Persistent in-migration to Calgary is mitigating the attainment of targets for this metric, despite the good membership results achieved.

Performance Measure Name: Overall satisfaction rating with Library services
Story behind the number: This measure is derived from a third-party phone survey conducted semi-annually. The goal is to increase this number. As respondents are selected randomly, they represent a broad spectrum of Library users, engaging with a wide variety of Library services. This measure has remained consistently high since 2019, showing considerable resilience during the years of the pandemic. It is indicative of the quality and breadth of the Library’s offerings.
